Ron,

Thank you for your imput!  My first thought was also the possibility=
 of
a well preserved nakago.  As far as determining if it is ubu or
o-suria=
ge unfortunately exceeds my expertise.  I've taken a few photos
and will po=
st them as soon as possible.  I was unable to capture all
aspects of my des=
cription in the pictures, but hopefully they will help.
The sori is 1.5 cm =
and is tori.  The blade as mentioned is a bit "
rough" but is overall healt=
hy.  I  detect no "drop off " running my
thumb and fore finger through the =
machi area.  Possibly another clue to
a later blade??

Thanks again,

Dave
=
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Ron Hartmann" <swords@...> wrote:
>
>=
 Ricky -
>
> >The hada is very prominant, it seems to be a Itame/Mokume mix=
 with
Masame near the ha. The Masame hada also can be >clearly seen through=

the kissaki...O-sugikai yasurime...suguha...
>
> All of this makes me thin=
k ko-to and not at all shinshin-to work. I
wonder if your sword's nakago is=
 simply well preserved, making you think
it is "newer" than it really is. A=
nytime I see a masame running along
the ha it makes me think "early" and st=
arts me looking for further
clues. The sword is relatively short; is the na=
kago original (ubu) or
could it be O-suriage? The mention of O-sugikai yasu=
rime makes me think
it is ubu, unsigned. It still makes me think ko-to with=
 Yamato
characteristic; sue-Tegai perhaps? You do not mention sori; I'm cur=
ious
what this is telling you. Any photos available???
>
> Ron
> STL
